author: jgm
content:
Things that matter:
  - getting in to your local beacon node's list of pending withdrawals (this stops an attacker from providing their own change operation)
  - having your operation broadcast to other nodes (this stops an attacker from propagating their own change operation)
Things that don't matter:
  - when the operation is included on-chain (at least, no one will care in a month)

author: .paulharris
content:
Maybe
 - Check if you even need to change your credentials - if you setup your validator with an ethereum withdrawal address, then this is not a process that will involve you...
 - If you do need to change your credentials, and you have no concerns for the security of your withdrawal mnemonic, then change it any time after capella, and there's no rush. Find a time that best suits you when you're not distracted and can spend a little time reading some documentation, You'll need an ethereum address that you can deposit funds to and definitely have control of... Make sure you still have the credentials for the ethereum address you're going to use, as the change is permanent for the validator.... etc .etc. 

There's definitely the number of bls changes on the withdrawals page, but I suspect the size of the bls change queue is a little less easy to see... and querying the api isn't something I'd probably suggest non tech users play with as they'll just find it frustrating, so that's the part of the story im not sure how to articulate in a way that everyone will get and be appropriate for their client...
